author: Kyoungwha Kim
title: China’s Stocks Plunge to Three-Month Lows as Bear Market Deepens
text:
Chinese stocks slumped, extending a bear-market rout, as government measures to shore up equities failed to stop margin traders from unwinding positions.
The Shanghai Composite Index sank 4.9 percent to 3,722.37 at 9:44 a.m. local time, dragged down by techology and industrial companies. The gauge has tumbled 28 percent from its June 12 peak, helping wipe out at least $2.8 trillion of value.
China’s markets regulator said Thursday it will investigate and “strictly” punish manipulation. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is examining recent short-selling activity for stock-index futures amid the slump, people with knowledge of the matter said. Regulators have made late-night announcements almost every day since the benchmark index entered a bear market this week.
“Chinese brokers may still be looking at reducing their risk exposure by closing more margin debt,” said Bernard Aw, a strategist at IG Asia Pte Ltd. in Singapore. “For now, the mood is verging on panic, and it is extremely hard to calm a bear who is in a rage.”
The outstanding balance of margin debt on Shanghai Stock Exchange dropped for a ninth day on Thursday, sliding to 1.29 trillion yuan ($208 billion) in the longest losing streak since the city’s bourse began to compile the data on March 31, 2010. The record of 1.48 trillion yuan was set on June 18.
